examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Can effectively debug or troubleshoot an SSIS Package/ETL
examples.2: Can create a basic (single source & type) SSIS Package/ETL to move data
examples.3: Can create advanced (multiple sources & types) SSIS Package/ETL with robust logging and error handling

C2.competency: Understands different types of ingestion patterns (file, SQL to SQL, Queues, APIs)

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Can create an ingestion process for filedrops or SQL to SQL patterns and understands how to use/set environment variables
examples.2: Understands all different ingestion methods currently used (file, SQL to SQL, Queues, APIs) and can create an ingestion process for at least two. Understands the difference between deployment models (package vs project) and when to use them.
examples.3: Creates docs, processes, templates, and examples for different ingestion use cases. Proactively seeks out new and better ingestion methods and tools.

C3.competency: Experience querying large tables on SQL Server

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Can write basic T-SQL syntax with joins and aggregates that is Sargable
examples.2: Good grasp of functions, window functions, and CTEs.
examples.3: Can write complex SQL and understands performance trade-offs.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Follows SSMS indexing suggestions. Looks for basic operations in query execution plan using SSMS or Sentry One Plan Explorer
examples.2: Creates columnstore and row indexes (not what SSMS suggests). Analyzes execution plan and uses stats to find real issues and other advanced features (join operators).
examples.3: Advanced understanding of the execution plan vs the data set and the best way to structure a query to achieve the business case.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands how a bus matrix is created and what its purpose is
examples.2: Knows the difference between star and snowflake schema and why Kimball uses star
examples.3: Understands how all models fit in to a global semantic framework and the business cases they solve for

C6.competency: Experience creating a relational database schema

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands partitioning/index types and standard metadata columns
examples.2: Implements basic partitioning and proper constraints
examples.3: Creates highly scalable schema(s) with a combination of indexing/partitioning

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands and implements kimball methodology
examples.2: Implements logical models using Kimball methodology and our current global standards
examples.3: Leads modeling design sessions and create new design patterns for data models

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands difference between OLAP and OLTP.
examples.2: Understands the impact indexes have on ingesting into OLTP model.
examples.3: Experience implementing an OLTP model.

examples.0: Does not look for code enhancements
examples.1: Actively improves code used in solutions regardless of the owner
examples.2: Uses Query Store or other similar tools to proactively find areas for enhancement and updates them
examples.3: Sets up proactive monitoring and alerting to check for quality issues (performance, error handling, logging, etc..)

B2.competency: Proactively researches new tools and technology

examples.0: Does not research new technologies or seek to understand technology decisions being made
examples.1: Seeks to understand technology decisions that have been made or are in progress
examples.2: Utilizes new technology on the train and proactively seeks out training
examples.3: Proactively migrates to utilizing new technologies and actively trains team members

examples.0: Does not follow best practices
examples.1: Seeks to understand and follow data engineering best practices
examples.2: Proactively teaches, researches, and recommends industry best practices
examples.3: Documents, rolls out, gets buy in, and follows through with the implementation of best practices

B4.competency: Follow quality standards (unit testing, error handling, regression testing, post-deployment validation)

examples.0: Does not follow quality standards
examples.1: Always validates business use case is met post-deployment
examples.2: Includes error handling and regression testing as a normal part of the development life cycle
examples.3: Performs unit testing as a normal part of the development life cycle

B5.competency: Utilizes source control systems in their development (GIT, Redgate, TFS, other)

examples.0: Does not utilize source control in their development
examples.1: Is able to perform basic functions in source control such as fork, commit, pull requests or equivalent
examples.2: Is able to perform more advanced functions in source control such as cloning and rebase or equivalent
examples.3: Is an expert and go to person in one or more source control systems

A1.competency: Knowledge of Tabular and Multi-Dimensional Cubes for Analytical Processing

examples.0: Has no knowledge of Tabular or Multi-Dimensional cubes
examples.1: Understands the basic concepts of Tabular or Multi-Dimensional cubes and why they are useful
examples.2: Understands advanced concepts (perspectives, partitioning, direct query) of Tabular cubes and technologies related to their development such as Azure Analysis Services
examples.3: Proactively seeks to understand data technology decisions, roadmap, and the implementation of the technology

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience
examples.1: Can create a Tabular model in SSDT
examples.2: Leverages Power Query/M when building the model
examples.3: Creates partitioning for optimal reporting (such as a hot partition.)

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience
examples.1: Can create simple measures, calculated columns, and tables using DAX
examples.2: Understands filter context
examples.3: Troubleshoots performance issues and identify root causes (system gateway, DAX, processing, rendering)

A4.competency: Knowledge of front-end reporting solutions (Power BI, SSRS, Tableau, QSlice)

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Knows which reporting solutions are legacy vs new
examples.2: Knows how the legacy reporting solutions are populated and the differences between how they receive data.
examples.3: Knows how all reporting solutions are populated and the difference between how they receive data.

A5.competency: Experience building datasets in various reporting solutions

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Experience building datasets in one reporting systems
examples.2: Experience building datasets in two legacy reporting systems and experience building a dataset in Power BI
examples.3: Mentored other on building datasets in legacy reporting systems as well as Power BI

A6.competency: Knowledge of Power BI as the reporting tool of choice

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands how to build a report and accompanying dataset
examples.2: Understands the Power BI architecture (report, service, gateways, datasets) and how it integrates into the BIG framework
examples.3: Documents how we utilize Power BI and shares it with other data engineers.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Can read an error log to troubleshoot basic issues such as kill long-running processes
examples.2: Understands and implements extended events
examples.3: Understands infrequently used system dmvs sush as sys.dm_db_page_info

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Is able to use perfmon, grafana, etc... to monitor health
examples.2: Takes action based on monitoring tools output
examples.3: Is able to setup monitoring for servers using perf mon, grafana, influx, etc...

SE1.competency: Understands data security within SQL Server

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands what is PII/PFI and how we control it with the access model (logins/roles/auditing)
examples.2: Leverages existing sensitive schemas
examples.3: Implements secure data models using security at the db, schema, table, and row level

SE2.competency: Understands data security when sharing and transmitting

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands privacy by design and legal implications
examples.2: Leverages existing sharing and transmitting model
examples.3: Creates a new process to improve security of data being shared and transmitting. Sets up auditing.

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Understands the basic Data Lake architecture
examples.2: Knows where to find the data I need in the Data Lake and can successfully query that data
examples.3: Not only can I effectively query the Data Lake, but I can build SSIS packages to retrieve data from the Data Lake and land it in DW

examples.0: Limited experience or knowledge. May have some familiarity but no hands-on or professional experience.
examples.1: Has some experience or knowledge. Can perform with limited oversight and guidance.
examples.2: Has production-level experience and deep hands-on knowledge. Can effectively share knowledge and assist others.
examples.3: Expert-level. Fully autonomous and can deliver consistently with an exceptional degree of quality.
